item.content:encoded:
– All the technique in the world doesn’t compensate for the inability to notice.

Truth is nobody is interested in seeing your photographs. Nobody cares about the work that you are doing as a photographer. Nobody cares about anybody’s work. You could take that a step further and say ‘you know the world really does not need any more photographers’. We have plenty, they are over-saturated, we do not need any more photographers, musicians, actors, writers we certainly do not need any more films produced. We are over-saturated there is too much stuff out there.

This isn’t necessarily a bitter truth but the world does need work that matters. Our survival as a culture is dependent on work that means something. The role arts have always played in our culture even has changed a lot over the years whether that is a ‘J. K. Rowling’ novel, whether that’s paintings on a cave wall, whether that’s many years later a Beethoven symphony, whether that’s the Sistine Chapel these are things that significantly matter in the history of the world.

We live in very complicated times. There are a lot of issues that if you consider that art plays a role in our lives that makes us think it creates awareness, sometimes it just makes us feel better about ourselves. It creates positivity. It creates many different kinds of energy that help us deal with who we are and where we’re going as people.

– Photography of the future

Now those are two different things ‘work that matters’ and ‘nobody wants to look at your photographs’. Point is that if you’re going to shoot just for you the truth is that there’s plenty of stuff out there.  Most people will not become known. A lot of people remain unknown and that’s just how it works. Work that matters is important and that’s what you should be striving to do. It is not a popularity contest; it is creating something that means something.

Photography in the next 5, 10 or 20 years is going to look very different. With mobile stuff with the internet with social media and those are just barely starting to mature. People see more images in a day that are displayed on a computer screen than they do in print or on a gallery wall.

To figure out what is that work that is going to matter. What are you trying to say as an artist. How do you go about doing and that is the challenge. It is not easy. It is not something you are going to discover in a couple minutes, an hour, weekend or even in a couple years. Sometimes it’s something that you’re constantly pursuing and working towards. It is important and like I said sure nobody wants to see my work or your work. Nobody cares, therefore we need work that makes a difference! We need work that means something!

item.content:encoded:
-The idea is fancy and revolutionary.

Intel’s smart glasses ‘Vaunt’ is completely different from what you are expecting, weighs about 50 grams and designed to do just one thing, show simple, basic information in one of the eyes. It has a red monochrome projector that shines an image on a holographic mirror. Light then bounces directly into the viewers eyeball. Best part is that if you are not looking slightly down at the display, it completely disappears.

There is no camera, it is meant to be non-intrusive, not annoying in social situations. Vaunt glasses are a prototype project from Intel’s new devices group. Later in 2018 developers are going to be able to start using them. These glasses need to be fitted to the wearer eyes’ interpupillary distance so that the display can line up to eyeball.

It uses a type of laser called a VCSEL (Vertical-cavity surface-emitting laser) – it is a low power class one laser & harmless to the human eye. A holographic grating is embedded in the lens to reflect the correct wavelengths back to the eye. The image is painted into the back of the wearer’s retina. If the wearer wears prescription glasses then it is used for looking at the world but not for the image. You can have terrible vision and still see bright, sharp, clear image that looks like it comes from Infinity.

Intel is also introducing a level of behavioral  A.I. to these glasses, a system that allows to figure out what to show you when. Intel glasses currently represents the most promising version of smart glasses that are in the market & is in the very early stage of development & like mobile phones this has the potential to become the next big thing!!!

item.content:encoded:
– Metaphysics of Teleportation

One of the deepest theological questions at the merger where physics and philosophy collide. In the present time, we can only teleport photons, particles of light and atoms like caesium and rubidium. However, in the coming years we do expect to be able to teleport molecules, maybe water, carbon dioxide. After that who knows? Maybe even DNA, maybe organic molecules.

Now to teleport a human raises ethical dilemma, because the original human body has to be destroyed in the process of quantum teleportation. Therefore, if Captain Kirk, zap himself across the room, you have now seen Captain Kirk die. You have seen his atoms fall apart, but here is this other Captain Kirk on the other side of the room who has the same bad jokes, who has the same character, all the personality quirks as the original Captain Kirk.

So the imposter says, “No, I’m real. I have the memories, the personality, and the quirks. I am Captain Kirk”. Well you just saw the original die and if you believe in a soul that soul went to heaven or maybe the other place, but that person is dead, so who is this imposter over there? Does the imposter have a soul? So it raises the question are we nothing but information? Is the soul, the essence of who we are, nothing but information? All we can say, it is physically possible to teleport an entire human being across the room or maybe onto Mars. It is physically possible to do that and it raises a valid question. What happened to the soul if your original copy died and somebody out there has all your memories? What does that mean? Answer is we don’t know.

In a little over a century, humankind has advanced from an uncertain new understanding of the behaviour of electrons at the atomic scale to reliably teleporting them across a room. What new technical mastery of such phenomena might we have in 1,000, or even 10,000 years? Only time and space will tell.

In the meanwhile! Beam me up SCOTTY!!!

item.content:encoded:
– A five point five pointer

 

A film starring Chris Hemsworth and Michael Shannon, 12 Strong’s narrative focuses on the first Special Forces team who are deployed to Afghanistan after 9/11. In an attempt to take down the Taliban, the team must work with an Afghan warlord while under the leadership of their new captain, Mitch played by Chris Hemsworth. Story is based on book entitled Horse Soldiers, which tells the story of CIA officers and U.S. Special Forces sent to Afghanistan immediately after 9/11. I really like the poster for this movie. It’s simple yet colorful but engaging.

Did I like it?Is it good?Is it AMAZING? IT IS………okay.

The problem that this movie has is that it’s slow moving. The story moves from one scene to the next without truly taking the time to allow the audience to absorb and feel the moment. This makes the movie feel dense, in that you don’t get a true understanding of these characters. You don’t get a full understanding of who they are. You do get a brief backstory of some of them in cast and their families, such as Chris Hemsworth, Michael Shannon, and Michael Pena’s characters, however, it’s not enough to create a foundation to understand who these characters are and understand why or how they’re responding to certain situations.

-Lack substance behind writing

This is not due to the fault of the actors, but the lack of substance behind the writing. This is not a terribly written movie, but the film suffers from the fact that the story always moves the characters, but the characters rarely move or progress the story. I didn’t hate this movie and although there have been quite a few 911 movies; this was definitely a story that world needs to know.

These men were deployed to Afghanistan literally right after the events of 911. You hear the events on the news and BOOM these men are out there fighting. In that regard, the movie does this story Justice. You can appreciate what these men are going through; these are the men you heard about on the news without truly knowing what was going on during the war. Although the score is nothing special, the visuals are quite good.

While the actors may not have many moments to shine in, the performances were still quite good, and the American heroism does shine at points in this movie. It’s unfortunate that some of these other factors weighted it down! With that being said it’s time for a final rating. Alright I’m going to give 12 Strong a 5.5 at best.

item.content:encoded:
One of the greatest battles in history

 

 

On September 12th 1897, more than 10,000 Afghan tribesmen attacked 21 soldiers of the Sikh regiment of the British Indian Army in a small mountain fort. This almost forgotten battle of Saragarhi along the famed Khyber Pass is one of the greatest last stands in history of the world. The history of the British Empire along the Northwest Frontier on the northwest side of British India was long and frequently bloody, their interests in Afghanistan began as early as the 18th century.

Afghanistan became a centrepiece and there was a political and military contest between the British Empire and the Russian Empire for influence in Central Asia between 1849 and 1947. The British fought three wars with the Afghan’s and there were numerous other small conflicts and punitive expeditions, a lot of that had to do with the disputed lands between the frontier of British India in what is now modern-day Pakistan and Afghanistan.

After a tribal uprising in 1891, the British decided they should fortify & garrison the Khyber Pass. Two chief fortifications Fort Gulistan and Fort Lockhart were built, two forts were just three miles apart but they could not see each other because in between there was a tall mountain and so the British built a small signalling post on top of that mountain facilitating communication between the two forts and came to be known as Fort Saragarhi.

The Battle

Five companies of the 36th Sikh regiment of the British Indian Army garrisoned these fortifications. Sikhs are followers of a pantheistic religion called Sikhism, they are concentrated in the Punjab region of India. In August of 1897, there was a general uprising of the Pashtun tribes and Fort Gulistan and Fort Lockhart came under the attack of more than 10,000 Afghan tribesmen. At that time the forts in the area were garrisoned by just around 500 members of the 36th Sikhs.  Fort’s came under sporadic fire but there wasn’t an all-out attack until mid-September. Because the two forts could reinforce each other the Afghans were unable to get to the fortifications.

On September 12th, Afghans decided to focus their attention on Fort Saragarhi. Manned by just 21 soldiers, 1 sergeant and 20 troopers from the 36th Sikhs. The attack could be viewed from Fort Lockhart and they counted seven different banners among the Afghan tribes. This allowed them to estimate how many Afghans were attacking, it was somewhere between 10 and 12 thousand.

Ground between them was open. There was little that the Garrison’s in Fort Gulistan and Fort Lockhart could do to help the soldiers on Saragarhi. Any reinforcements would had to fight their way through the ten thousand Afghanis. However, there were reinforcements coming from farther down the pass. The 21 troopers decided that instead of trying to escape or surrendering they would fight and hold out as long as they could fight to the last in order to give the most time for those reinforcements to come.

Frustration of Afghans

Since it was a signalling post, they were able to use their heliograph to inform the troops at Fort Lockhart about the details of the battle. The attack commenced around 9:00 am. Fort was only stoned and mudded. It was tall and was on top of a mountain, the Afghans could not bring their numbers to bear. The defenders who could concentrate their fire were able to repulse several attacks. Casualties were slowly reducing them and they were running out of ammunition.

After two determined attempts to force the door were repulsed. Afghans finally became frustrated and set fire to the bushes in the area. They were able to move under the cover of the smoke to one of the walls. It could not be observed and undermine the wall creating a breach. They stormed in and became bloody hand fighting to the end. Last defender remaining was the one who had been running the heliograph. Since he was up on a tower he could observe what was going on down below. From fort Lockhart they could see him shooting into the Afghanis. He killed as many as 20 before the frustrated Afghan’s set fire to the tower and let him die in the flames.

Aftermath

By then it was after 3 p.m. The defenders of Saragarhi had held out for more than six hours. That gave the reinforcements much time to come. Reinforcements got to the ruins of fort Saragarhi they found more than 600 dead afghan tribesmen around the fort. They were able to drive off the attack with artillery and saved the forts.

The British responded with a huge punitive expedition that involved more than 30,000 troops known as Terra campaign. British stomped the valley burning all the villages, destroying all the fortifications until the tribes were forced to sue for peace. All twenty-one defenders of Fort Saragarhi were awarded the Indian Order of Merit. Which was the highest award for Indian troops in the British Indian Army, the equivalent of a Victoria Cross.

This battle is remembered every year on the 12th of September as Saragarhi Day among Sikh units of the Indian Army, but it is largely forgotten everywhere else. May the sacrifice of these 21 brave solders live in our hearts “jo bole so nihal sat sri akal”!!!

item.content:encoded:
This could be the worst movie I have ever seen!

 

Last night I attended screening of Downsizing, starring Matt Damon, Kristen Wiig, & Christoph Waltz. I had high expectations but it definitely was very bad. What surprised me was just HOW bad it was and why. So I’m going to warn you ahead of time.

Matt Damon is good at one thing: playing an average guy who gets into unusual situations, this is exactly what he does here. The main gist of the movie is that it’s possible for people to be shrunk to be like 5 inches tall, so they could live in smaller communities where everything costs less.

Someone who is just an average middle class man in the outside world can live like a king in the leisure-land (where all shrunken population lives). Matt Damon’s character gets shrunk, but his wife – Kristen Wiig – gets cold feet. So, what can you do with this story from this point? It’s a somewhat enticing premise.

The film becomes an in-your-face preachy tirade about the injustices of the world. It tries to address things like income inequality, illegal immigration, human trafficking, and a whole lot more. Basically, this movie is just a vehicle for Matt Damon, and whoever wrote this garbage, to jab you in your face with what can only be described as their guilt over being white Americans.

Somehow there are shrunken refugees from third world countries, shrunken illegal immigrants, shrunken poor people who live in shanties outside the walls of the tiny world, that for some reason have a public bus route that goes there?!? The social injustice commentary is so thick and so heavy-handed that it is beyond offensive and ridiculous.

It’s insulting to the viewer. Additionally, I had a hard time getting over the ridiculousness of the whole concept, mostly due to the sloppy way it was all handled in this film. The blatant disregard for some basic laws of physics and common sense just really dug at me.

They just added a few oversized objects here and there, so that you believe that the people in the scenes are 5 inches tall instead of being normal size humans. There is hardly anything at all to like in this movie; it is not worth seeing an offensively bad movie for I have zero desire to contemplate the human condition after watching this.

I just have a desire to never watch another Matt Damon movie again. If you want to make the world a better place, then be up front with it. Don’t inject your preachy narrative where it doesn’t belong. Leave a mediocre comedy be a mediocre comedy.

Had they continued with the going-on-a-self-discovery-journey plot-line, this would have just been another silly and forgettable movie. Instead it is as offensive as a pile of poop on a dining room table. I’m sorry, Matt Damon and whoever, but you can go screw yourselves. So, in case I wasn’t clear in this. This movie sucks and you shouldn’t waste your time on it. That’s it.

item.content:encoded:
Martin Luther King JR

A minister, a poet, a lover of words & freedom. He was a family man, a talented speaker, a seeker of truth & justice. He met every challenge he faced. By the time he went home to god, he was already an American icon! He was Martin Luther King JR. Born as Michael Luther King JR. later in life changed his name to Martin. His grandfather and father were pastors of the Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta. The family legacies served there since 1914 & from 1960 until his death, Martin Luther King JR. acted as co-pastor alongside his father.

Martin attended segregated public schools in Georgia, graduating from high school at the age of 15 after skipping two grades. he was a talented young man receiving his Bachelor of the Arts degree in 1948 from Morehouse College a distinguished institution in Atlanta which both his father and grandfather graduated from. After three years of theological study at Crozer Theological Seminary he was awarded bachelors of Divinity in 1951, he then enrolled in graduate studies at Boston University and received his PhD in 1955 in Boston.

Birth of a Hero

In Boston, he also met and married Coretta Scott an intellectual and artistic young woman. They bore two sons and two daughters; in 1954, Martin Luther King became pastor of the Dexter Avenue Baptist Church in Montgomery Alabama. He was a strong advocate for civil rights in the black community; he held a position in the executive committee of then NAACP, the leading civil rights advocates at that time. As a member, one of his tasks was to organize the first great civil rights protest ever to occur in United States contemporary history. This was a 382 day long bus boycott in Montgomery Alabama. At the time people of different races were not allowed to ride in the same sections of the bus and sometimes not even on the same buses at all.

The boycott would prove to be quite effective for, on December 21st 1956 the Supreme Court of the United States declared unconstitutional all the laws requiring segregation on buses. during this boycott. King was arrested, his home was bombed, he was subject to personal abuse but at the same time he emerged as a hero in the Civil Rights community. Martin Luther King JR. is not just famous however for his ‘I have a dream’ speech, what is the most outstanding is he based his entire model for the non-violent movement.

The protests

On his experience as a Christian minister he led massive protests that caught the attention of the entire world. All stemming from his belief that all men are created equal under God. Before a crowd of nearly 250,000 people he made a proclamation, and that proclamation was that we should not be judged by the color of our skin but rather by the content of our character and his character was one of greatness, one that will be remembered in the history books as a man beyond reproach.

A man who received the Nobel Peace Prize at the age of 35. A man who has given distinguished honors from leaders all over the world. A champion for the rights of those who have none. Would that he were with us today but alas it is not so. A sniper ended his life on April 4th of his motel room in Memphis Tennessee. But though the man died that day his legacy lives on.  It lives on in the hearts of those who are like-minded.

Followers seeking true equality. Not the fraudulent equality that puts one above another. But a truly color blind equality and one that values each personas a child of God. And as children of God ourselves we must do all that we can to make sure that his dream is upheld. His legacy is not forgotten. That we too may join on that triumphant day in saying free at last free at last. Thank God Almighty we are free at last.

item.content:encoded:
Demonetization: A failure or a success

Night of November 8th 2016, Prime Minister Modi in a 48 minutes address to the nation announced 500 & 100 rupees notes amounting to 86.4% all currency in circulation in India (14 lakh crore rupees or roughly about US$200+billion ) would be illegal as of midnight, 3 hours is what he gave the country to pull 86% of the country’s money out of
circulation and this in a country where cash represents 98% of all transactions by volume. 

Within days real result of Modi’s announcement became apparent. There was severe disruption of regular economic activity. Over 90% of the financial transactions happens in cash, and over 85% of workers depend on it.  Everyday economy came to a grinding halt. Lack of planning unleashed anarchy on the economy and insecurity amongst people.

Banks did not have enough currency printed, not even a fraction of what was enough to meet the consumer demand for new notes so they restricted withdrawals to small amounts of cash that were insufficient for most people.

Bigger question arises, under which provision of the law can an Indian citizen be denied access to his own account? Can Modi name one country in the world that disallows people from withdrawing money from their own bank accounts? RBI told the Public Accounts Committee On January 18th 2017 that it was up to 60%, SBI estimated it may go up to 70% by end of February 2017, the economic survey claims it will all be back by the end of March 2017.

Inadequacies in printed currency.

Even more in-efficiency came to light they started printing notes but didn’t print enough quantity of the smaller notes, so people were lucky to get two thousand rupee note but no one could make change for it.

furthermore there was even more inefficiency with the ATM’s and it never occurred to the government to realize that if they want to put new notes into the existing ATMs they should be the same size as the old notes but they made them a different size so they won’t fit into the ATMs and then they hire 50k+ engineers across the banking system to recalibrate the machine.

The fastest growing economy in the world can no longer boast of a booming economy, it has suddenly become a cash scarce economy, production went down in all sectors, small producers could not get working capital, some businesses have had to shut down daily wage workers who are a majority of the labor force in our country, many of them lost their jobs because firms didn’t have the cash to pay them.

The economic survey published by the Finance Ministry states “these demonetization is an aggregate demand shock an aggregate supply shock and uncertainty shock and liquidity shock”. All India manufacturer’s organizations, macro and small-scale industries and traders have incurred 60% job losses & 47% revenue losses because of the demonetization. Large infrastructure companies they’ve surveyed have reported a 35% drop in employment and 45% drop in revenue.

Unemployed India

Construction industry which employs four and a half crore people has virtually ground to a halt. A drop of 80% to 90% in revenues, there’s even been an inventory pileup because there’s no consumer demand. Former Prime Minister Dr Manmohan Singh estimated that the GDP of India would shrink by 1 to 2%. Local industries footwear in Agra, garments in other parts of the country, rubber in Kerala and transport everywhere slowed down, in many cases had to be suspending their work for lack of money.

The informal financial sector, rural money lenders who provide loans that amount to 40% of our total lending that’s infrastructure has all but collapsed inside rural India. Fishing industry depend entirely on cash sales. This has even affected coastal security. Number of boats going out to sea severely reduced. Because of the demonetization that’d be a fewer eyes and ears looking for suspicious activity in the maritime waters. Traders are losing variable stocks, farmers are dumping their produce. Foreigners suffered because of demonetization.  Tourism prevails by word of mouth, how will you bring back the trust of foreigners who spread the word of their harrowing ordeal in demonetized India.

Where is black money!

The damage is so extreme that the pain inflicted is outweighed by any tangible gain. What was again “let’s take black money” for example. The estimate was that many people rather than attract the attention of the law enforcement authorities and of the tax authorities would not return their money. They would destroy their black money. Various agencies estimated around 25% to 35% of the specified bank notes would not be deposited. The government expected that four to five lakh crores (US$60 billion to US$100 billion) would be rendered worthless on account of not being deposited. what happened!?

It seems that black money holders found creative ways of laundering their money and the result is that most of the estimated black money in circulation this four to five lakh crores that the Attorney General mentioned has flooded into the banks, now it seems that some well-placed friends of the ruling party may well have been allegedly tipped off because the well-connected clearly were able to unload their money, none of them seem terribly troubled by the November announcement.

By the end of December 95% to 97% of the money in circulation reached the banking system. In our eyes it looks like at most you will have 2% to 3% demonetized banknotes undeposited. So the primary objective of cleansing the economy, we can now forget it. In fact the RBI governor himself considered there is no impact at all.

The corruption

Now as we all know, all cash is not black money, all black money is not cash.  Most of it is invested in real estate, golden jewelry, investments abroad. Round-tripping that has seen the money returned to India stock markets as foreign investment from countries like Mauritius. After demonetization the income-tax department announced it had seized 500 crore rupees (US$5 billion). Unaccounted cash and strikingly 92 crores (US$.92 billion) of that black money happened to be new notes, so what’s going on!? 

 Some bank managers are over sitting in their banks from 9:00 to 5:00 telling people they had no money. From 5:00 to 9:00 in the evening they were getting money out the backdoor to those who could launder it. The government’s drive against corruption. They have created new forms of corruption. Clearly it has merely changed color and shape that money has become white.

If you’re going to bring new notes then you have to have strong security features with the design in order to prevent counterfeiting but it seems the government has missed the opportunity to put incredible security features in the new notes. There’s no new watermark, no new security thread or fiber, no new latent image and certainly no nano chip; so will a mere color change of color and size make them safe?

People’s suffering

Shockingly RBI  printed three different versions of the 500 rupee note. If all three versions are authentic. Is that going to confuse the public and make it easier for counterfeiters?

Under the supervision of the government’s own national investigation agency. The estimates of fake currency notes in circulation is only 400 crores or roughly 0.03% of the currency withdrawn. It also indicated that the ability of banks to prevent these notes being deposited was limited because a sudden announcement & short deadlines. Lots of money flooding in and the machines couldn’t tell the fake notes to tellers.

Housewives salted away their savings in biscuit tins, stories of individual tragedies have been mentioned, hospitals turning away patients, suffering middle-class, wage earners unable to buy medicine for the sick, 115 people reportedly dying, demonetization resulted in an increase in domestic violence cases, so the people at the bottom of the economic pyramid have been the real victims of this policy.
